title-group.article-title: A Negative Binomial Regression Model for Accuracy Tests

author-notes.corresp: Lai-Fa Hung, Chang Jung Christian University, No. 396, Sec. 1, Changrong Rd., Gueiren Dist., Tainan City 71101, Taiwan Email: r8702@ms14.hinet.net

abstract.p: Rasch used a Poisson model to analyze errors and speed in reading tests. An important property of the Poisson distribution is that the mean and variance are equal. However, in social science research, it is very common for the variance to be greater than the mean (i.e., the data are overdispersed). This study embeds the Rasch model within an overdispersion framework and proposes new estimation methods. The parameters in the proposed model can be estimated using the Markov chain Monte Carlo method implemented in WinBUGS and the marginal maximum likelihood method implemented in SAS. An empirical example based on models generated by the results of empirical data, which are fitted and discussed, is examined.

body.p: In educational measurement, tests can be classified into three types: pure speed tests, pure power tests, and a combination of these (Roskam, 1987; van Breukelen, 1989; White, 1982). Reading speed is considered an important aspect of reading ability, which for children can be evaluated in terms of accuracy and fluency. In item response theory (IRT), Rasch (1960) proposed a Poisson model (PM) for analyzing the reading performance of children. The PM can be used to analyze reading correctness (or errors), which is calculated using the total number of words correctly (or incorrectly) read in a test with a fixed number of words. For fluency, the PM (or exponential density) can be used to analyze the reading speed, which is evaluated using the time spent reading a fixed number of words. The present study focuses on the issue of accuracy.

When person
i
(
i = 1 ,… , N
) responds to test
j
(
j = 1 ,… , J
), the PM can be expressed as follows:

where

(

) is the number of words correctly (or incorrectly) read by person
i
in test

.
λ
ij
is the intensity or rate parameter, for which Rasch assumed the following multiplicative decomposition:

where
θ
i
is the ability of person
i
and
b
j
is the ease (or difficulty) of test
j
. Higher values of ability and ease correspond to fewer expected response errors.

Numerous models similar to the Rasch PM (RPM) have been proposed. Scheiblechner (1979) extended the Rasch model with an additive instead of a multiplicative decomposition in the person and item parameters. He assumed the exponential density for response time
t
ij
of person
i
on item
j
, that is, the density
f (
t
ij
) = λ exp ( − λ
t
ij
)
, with a parameterization of the mean/scale parameter λ > 0 as
λ =
θ
i
+
b
j
. Taking the correctness of power tests and the response time of speed tests into consideration, the RPM became the Rasch Response Time Model (Roskam, 1987). Van Breukelen (1989) proposed a Rasch Weibull Model that uses a hazard function that increases with time, is proportional to the person’s mental speed, and is inversely proportional to the test (item) difficulty and to the person’s persistence in continuing to work on the test (item). Originally, the RPM was formulated for complete data, with the test difficulty parameters and person ability parameters considered fixed. Because these restrictions may be too stringent in practice, Jansen (1995) expanded Rasch’s model by assuming the Poisson parameter to be a product of a fixed test difficulty and a Gamma-distributed random person ability parameter for treating incomplete data. Van Duijn and Jansen (1995) then extended the RPM to allow the person ability parameters to be random variables with a Gamma distribution and the random test difficulty parameters per participant (i.e., the test difficulty varies with participant) to follow a Dirichlet distribution. In such a model, the intensity parameter is
λ
ij
=
θ
i
b
ij
, where
b
ij
denotes the test difficulty parameter for person
i
in test
j
. The parameter
b
ij
represents the intraparticipant differences (interactions) between participants and tests, which makes the model more flexible for describing the interactions within a common Dirichlet distribution. If
b
ij
s are all equal for all participants (i.e.,
b
ij
=
b
j
), then Jansen’s model is obtained. Furthermore, the RPM can be expressed as the Partial Credit Model (Masters, 1982) or Rating Scale Model (Andrich, 1978). For more details about the RPM, refer to the studies of Meyer (2010), Muraki (1997), Schnipke and Scrams (2002), and Wright and Masters (1982).

In Equation 2, considering

sec.title: Negative Binomial Regression Model (NBRM)
sec.p: When used with the PM to analyze correctness (or errors) in reading tests, the data structure must fit the principle of equidispersion (i.e., the mean and variance are equal). In contrast, analytical results produce incorrect statistical inferences from an overdispersed data structure (Lindsey, 1993; Thall & Vail, 1990). In social science research, it is very common for the data variance to be greater than the mean. To deal with this, an additional random-effect term can be incorporated to handle the extra-Poisson variation (Engel, 1984; Lawless, 1987; Manton, Woodbury, & Stallard, 1981).
This study embeds the Rasch model within an extra-Poisson framework and proposes new estimation methods. Corresponding to Jansen’s (2003) model, the proposed model is expressed as follows:

where

Note that although the estimations of the mean and variance of the NBRM can be obtained using Equation 5, these are population parameters, not measurements at the level of an individual. sec.title: Parameter Estimation
sec.p: In the past, the parameters of the Rasch model for reading tests were estimated using the conditional maximum likelihood (CML) method (Jansen, 1995; Scheiblechner, 1979) or the marginal maximum likelihood (MML) method (Jansen, 1995, 2003; Jansen & van Duijn, 1992). It is important to have estimation methods for dealing with overdispersion in regression models. In this study, the proposed estimation methods use not only the MML method but also a Bayesian method based on Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) algorithms. However, implementing Bayesian analysis is computationally intensive and cumbersome for programming. Fortunately, the computer program WinBUGS is a convenient tool for simple and complicated Bayesian models, and features various MCMC-based algorithms (Hung & Wang, in press).

sec.title: MML Estimation
sec.p: Suppose that a set of J tests is used to measure a given trait. For MML, a likelihood function can be expressed as follows:
The first-order and second-order derivatives of the likelihood function are, respectively, formulated as follows:

The MML can be solved iteratively using the Newton–Raphson (NR) method or other numerical analyses. For a complete discussion of the NR method, see the studies of Gourieroux, Monfort, and Trognon (1984); Lawless (1987); Maddala (1983); and van Duijn (1993).

For the individual ability parameters, the prior Gamma distributions of
λ
ij
are assumed; thus, the MML estimators for the ability parameters can be easily derived analytically. The individual ability estimates are
ς
^

= log ( (

− 1
+ exp (

(see also Jansen, 2003; van Duijn & Jansen, 1995).

sec.title: MCMC Algorithms
sec.p: Recent interest in Bayesian methods might be due to the complex dependency structures in IRT models requiring the evaluation of multiple integrals to solve the estimation equations in an MML approach (Fox & Glas, 2001; Patz & Junker, 1999). The major advantage of the Bayesian framework is that modern computer-intensive techniques, such as MCMC algorithms, can often simplify the parameter estimation problem (Baker, 1998; De Boeck & Wilson, 2004; Wollack, Bolt, Cohen, & Lee, 2002). There are various MCMC algorithms, including the Metropolis–Hastings (M-H) algorithm (Hastings, 1970; Metropolis, Rosenbluth, Rosenbluth, Teller, & Teller, 1953) and the Gibbs sampling algorithm (Baker, 1998; Fox & Glas, 2001; Liu & Sabatti, 2000; Roberts & Smith, 1993), with the latter used in this study. The most prominent feature of the Gibbs sampling algorithm is that the underlying Markov chain is constructed by composing a sequence of posterior distributions along a set of directions (Hung & Wang, in press). Because the model used in this article is a Poisson–Gamma model, which follows a conjugate distribution, Gibbs sampling can recognize conjugate specifications so that the corresponding nodes can be updated via direct sampling algorithms.

As a first step in the Bayesian approach, the prior distributions for all model parameters
η
are specified to form a posterior distribution. Let
P ( η )
be the prior distribution of
η
. The core of the Bayesian modeling process requires the evaluation of the posterior distribution of
η
given
y
obs
: P
( η
|
y
obs
)
∝ P (
y
obs
| η
) P
( η )
. The general strategy underlying the Gibbs sampling algorithm is as follows:

Sample each parameter from its posterior distribution conditioned on the previous values sampled for the other parameters:
Sample a second set of parameters from their posterior distributions conditioned on the last set of parameters, to form the second iteration:
Continue this iterative process until a large number of samples is generated.

sec.title: Deviance Information Criterion (DIC)
sec.p: The DIC (Spiegelhalter, Best, Carlin, & van der Linde, 2002; Spiegelhalter, Thomas, Best, & Lunn, 2003) is defined as a Bayesian measure of the model-data fit:

where
D ( )
is the deviance of the model.

The average of the posterior samples of

η

D

is a point estimate of the deviance, and
PD
is the effective number of parameters.

Other criterion indices used as a fit measure are the Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC; Schwarz, 1978) and the Akaike Information Criterion (AIC; Akaike, 1973, 1974), which are calculated, respectively, using the following:
and

where negative two times the log likelihood is the deviance, p is the number of parameters to be estimated, and
N
is the sample size. For all three indices (DIC, BIC, and AIC), smaller values suggest a better model fit.

sec.title: Empirical Example
sec.p:
An application of these methods to data obtained from an accuracy test is discussed in this section. A total of 360 Grade 4 students (173 females and 187 males) were asked to read three paragraphs (a total of 159 words). Table 1 contains a number of descriptive statistics. Dependent variable
y
is the number of response errors (misread words);
x
1
is the training variable (
x
1
= 1
means the examinee had received pronunciation training; otherwise,
x
1
= 0
);
x
2
is the family language type (
x
2
= 1
means the examinee is from a Mandarin-speaking family; otherwise,
x
2
= 0
);
x
3
is the examinee’s verbal comprehension score. As shown in Table 1, approximately 60% of the examinees had received pronunciation training, the numbers of examinees from Mandarin-speaking and non-Mandarin-speaking (e.g., Taiwanese, Hakka, etc.) families were almost the same, the average verbal comprehension score was approximately 80, and the average number of misread words was about 4. Note that the variance of
y
is 8.243, which is greater than the mean of
y
; therefore, overdispersion exists in this case.

caption.p: Descriptive Statistics for the Real-Data Analysis (N = 360)

sec.p:
Nine models were fitted and compared; their features are listed in Table 2. Model 1 (denoted as M1) was a PM with an equidispersion structure. Model 2 (denoted as M2) was an NBRM with only an intercept term. Models 3 through 5 (M3-M5) were NBRMs, with M3 having an intercept and
x
1
, M4 having an intercept and
x
2
, and M5 having an intercept and
x
3
. Models 6 through 8 (M6-M8) were NBRMs, with M6 having an intercept,
x
1
, and
x
2
; M7 having an intercept,
x
2
, and
x
3
; and M8 having an intercept,
x
1
, and
x
3
. Model 9 (M9) was an NBRM with an intercept and all independent variables.

caption.p: Comparison of Model-Data Fit for the Real-Data Analysis

fn.p: Note: AIC = Akaike’s Information Criterion; BIC = Bayesian Information Criterion; DIC = Deviance Information Criterion; PM = Poisson model; NBRM = negative binomial regression model.

sec.p: Used with the Gibbs sampling algorithm, the two integral aims of an MCMC estimation are to determine the number of initial iterations to discard (i.e., the burn-in) and to determine whether a sufficient number of draws have been obtained, as this allows the inference about the posterior distribution to be well estimated (Wollack et al., 2002). The recommended burn-in lengths provided by the convergence diagnostic of Geweke (1992) and Gelman and Rubin (1992) are between 10 and 63 iterations. Geyer (1992) and Patz and Junker (1999) suggested that a reasonable burn-in length is the number of lags needed to obtain negligible autocorrelations. In this study, the autocorrelations of the Markov chains for most of the parameters rapidly approached 0 when the lag between draws was set to 50. The current analysis used a burn-in of 1,000 iterations to ensure that the Markov chain had reached a stationary distribution (Hung, 2010).
In this study, all the parameters were given vague priors:

A total of 12,000 iterations were used to provide sufficient convergence for all model parameters. The remaining 11,000 iterations were used to provide sampled parameter values for posterior summarization. To obtain accurate estimates, the Monte Carlo error for each parameter of interest should be smaller than 5% of the standard deviation (Spiegelhalter et al., 2003).

MCMC method (WinBUGS):

The negative weight for
x
2
indicates that examinees who were not from Mandarin-speaking families had, on average, more errors than those from Mandarin-speaking ones. As shown in Tables 3 and 4, the dispersion parameter and the variance of ability are about 0.24 and 0.27, respectively. In Model 6, for
x
1
= 1
and
x
2
= 1
, the difficulty of the test is 1.1. A participant with a perfect score has an ability estimate of about 2.67. In contrast, a participant with a score of 0 has an ability estimate of about −0.55.

To evaluate the effects of overdispersion in the empirical study, the likelihood ratio test (LRT) was used to test
H
0
: c = 0
versus
H
1
: c ≠ 0
; the statistical result is significant (
G
2
= 104 . 7
, with
df = 1
), meaning that overdispersion exists. This is confirmed by the BIC result (
Δ = 98 . 9
). As such, modeling the empirical example data with the NBRM is more appropriate than modeling it with the PM.

The model fit statistics are shown in Table 2. According to the
− 2 × log likelihood
statistics, M9, the NBRM with an intercept and all independent variables, is the model with the best fit. However, according to the BIC and DIC statistics, M6, the NBRM with an intercept,
x
1
, and
x
2
, is the model with the best fit. In model comparisons, such disagreements between the fit statistics are very common (Glueck, Machat, Jirasko, & Rollett, 2002; Hong & Min, 2007). Between the two competing models, the one with the intercept,
x
1
, and
x
2
(M6) was eventually chosen because of the following three considerations. First, because the BIC and DIC statistics are recommended more frequently in the literature (Hong & Min, 2007; Read & Cressie, 1988; Rost, 1996), they are emphasized here. Second, the simpler model was selected for reasons of parsimony. Third, the parameter
β
3
of M9 approaches 0, and when
β
3
is set to 0, Model M9 becomes Model M6.

sec.title: Simulation Analysis
sec.p:
To further evaluate the performance of M6 in the empirical study, data based on the true model were generated. Here, the author focuses on the results from M1, M6, and M9. For M1, the purpose of the simulations was to explore the statistical bias generated by misspecified models (e.g., overdispersion rather than equidispersion) and to compare efficacy under various conditions. For M6 and M9, the model fit indices were used to determine how accurately the true model can be selected (Zhang & Nesselroade, 2007). The parameters were set at
β
0
= 0 . 97
,
β
1
= 0 . 45
,
β
2
= − 0 . 31
,
β
3
= 0
, and
c = 0 . 25
. A total of 100 replications were generated. The same priors and iterations as in the empirical analysis were used.

sec.title: Analysis
sec.p: To evaluate the accuracy of the parameter estimates, three parameter recovery measures were computed:

where
ς
is the parameter of interest, and
R
is the number of replications. Bias is the average difference between the estimated and the true parameters. RMSE is the root mean square error between a parameter and its estimate. ARB is the absolute relative bias; if
ARB < 0 . 05
, the parameter recovery is satisfactory (Hoogland & Boomsma, 1998).

To further determine how accurately the true model can be selected, in addition to the DIC mentioned earlier, the extensions of AIC and BIC, namely, EAIC and EBIC, respectively (Spiegelhalter et al., 2002), were used. They are calculated, respectively, using
and

where
D
¯
,
p
, and
N
are defined as above. For EAIC and EBIC, smaller values suggest a better model fit.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The simulation analytical results are shown in Tables 5 and 6. The true values of the parameters are very well recovered on average despite the intercept parameters. In terms of the MML results, the bias was −0.385 to 0.001, the RMSE was 0.003 to 0.384, and the ARB was 0.000 to 0.397. The largest bias and RMSE values (−0.385 and 0.384, respectively) were obtained when the generated data were fitted to model M1. In terms of the MCMC results, the bias was −0.473 to 0.004, the RMSE was 0.004 to 0.474, and the ARB was 0.004 to 0.488. The largest bias and RMSE values (−0.473 and 0.474, respectively) were obtained when the generated data were fitted to model M1. The bias and RMSE of M1 were serious. In short, the NBRM always yielded smaller bias and RMSE values compared with those of the PM. That is, including the random-effect term in the model led to a smaller bias and RMSE. Where the data were generated from M6 with a random-effect structural model, the parameter estimates derived from the true model were much closer to the true values than the parameter estimates derived from M1 with a fixed-effect (misspecified) model.

caption.p: Parameter Recovery (Bias, RMSE, and ARB, Average of 100 Replications) for the Simulation Analysis From SAS

fn.p: Note: RMSE = root mean square error; ARB = absolute relative bias.

caption.p: Parameter Recovery (Bias, RMSE, and ARB, Average of 100 Replications) for the Simulation Analysis From WinBUGS

fn.p: Note: RMSE = root mean square error; ARB = absolute relative bias.

sec.p:
The comparison of model-data fit in the simulation analysis, as shown in Table 7, reveals that all the fit indices of M1 are larger than those of M6 and M9, suggesting that the random-effect model is well suited for the data structure. Furthermore, when comparing M6 and M9, according to the
− 2 × log likelihood
statistic, M9 is the model with the best fit. However, according to the other fit indices, M6 is the best. In terms of model selection, only 37, 16, 41, 32, and 14 out of 100 replications M9 based on AIC, BIC, DIC, EAIC, and EBIC, respectively. The five indices correctly chose the true model 63, 84, 59, 68, and 86 times out of 100 replications, respectively (Table 8). Generally speaking, the model selection methods correctly chose the true model the majority of the time.

caption.p: Comparison of Model-Data Fit for the Simulation Analysis (Average of 100 Replications)

fn.p: Note: AIC = Akaike’s Information Criterion; BIC = Bayesian Information Criterion; DIC = Deviance Information Criterion; EAIC = Extension of Akaike’s Information Criterion; EBIC = Extension of Bayesian Information Criterion.

Note: AIC = Akaike’s Information Criterion; BIC = Bayesian Information Criterion; DIC = Deviance Information Criterion; EAIC = Extension of Akaike’s Information Criterion; EBIC = Extension of Bayesian Information Criterion. The values indicate how many times the model was chosen based on the fit statistics.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The Rasch model within an extra-Poisson framework and an MCMC method was proposed in this study, and the implications and applications of the proposed model were demonstrated through analyses of accuracy test data. The treatment of the random-effect within the Gibbs sampling scheme is straightforward. Furthermore, this study demonstrated the feasibility of using Bayesian methods by employing simulations and empirical analysis.

In the small-scale simulation studies described here, the recovery of the parameters of a regression model for the test parameters was studied using MML and MCMC methods. As mentioned earlier, when the data were generated from the NBRM, the parameter estimates derived from the model were much closer to the true values than those derived from the PM. The analytical results reveal that model misspecification can lead to poor estimation.

The empirical analysis shows that the accuracy test data were overdispersed. The NBRM with an intercept,
x
1
, and
x
2
fitted the data statistically better than the other models. In contrast, the biggest difference with the PM is that all the fit indices drastically drop after taking the random-effect term into consideration, which shows that the random effect is undeniably important when interpreting this material. The best fit was obtained with a random-effect term, implying that there are individual differences in the importance of a person’s underlying traits in explaining the test. It is thus important to deal with extra-Poisson variation in a regression model. The NBRM discussed in this article is particularly convenient for this.

Some limitations need to be noted. First, to identify the resulting model,
α
i
was defined as identical across all persons (i.e.,
α
i
= α
). Although this restriction can be relaxed, the complexity of the model and difficulty of interpreting it will increase. Second, the analytical results are based on when the prior
λ
ij
was sampled from a Gamma distribution. The feasibility of using distributions other than the Gamma distribution may be further investigated. Third, as for the analysis of the empirical example comparing the models for all fit indices, smaller values suggest a better model fit. There is no criterion, however, by which to decide how large an improvement is needed in a given fit index to make the model selection determinant. Therefore, alternative model fit statistics need to be further considered (Hung, 2010; Zhang & Nesselroade, 2007). Finally, extending the extra-Poisson variation model to a multidimensional model containing multiple latent traits is possible and straightforward, and thus should be considered in future research.
